Package: io.vertx.groovy.core.streams

[Groovy] Class WriteStreamImpl<T>

    • io.vertx.groovy.core.streams.WriteStreamImpl

      @CompileStatic
class WriteStreamImpl

      • Property Detail

        • final WriteStream delegate

      • Constructor Detail

        • WriteStreamImpl(WriteStream delegate)

      • Method Detail

        • WriteStream<T> drainHandler(Handler<Void> handler)

          Set a drain handler on the stream. If the write queue is full, then the handler will be called when the write queue has been reduced to maxSize / 2. See Pump for an example of this being used.

          Returns:
          a reference to this, so the API can be used fluently
          Parameters:
          handler - the handler

        • WriteStream<T> exceptionHandler(Handler<Throwable> handler)

          Set an exception handler on the write stream.

          Returns:
          a reference to this, so the API can be used fluently
          Parameters:
          handler - the exception handler

        • Object getDelegate()

        • WriteStream<T> setWriteQueueMaxSize(int maxSize)

          Set the maximum size of the write queue to maxSize. You will still be able to write to the stream even if there is more than maxSize bytes in the write queue. This is used as an indicator by classes such as Pump to provide flow control.

          Returns:
          a reference to this, so the API can be used fluently
          Parameters:
          maxSize - the max size of the write stream

        • WriteStream<T> write(T data)

          Write some data to the stream. The data is put on an internal write queue, and the write actually happens asynchronously. To avoid running out of memory by putting too much on the write queue, check the WriteStream.writeQueueFull method before writing. This is done automatically if using a Pump.

          Returns:
          a reference to this, so the API can be used fluently
          Parameters:
          data - the data to write

        • boolean writeQueueFull()

          This will return true if there are more bytes in the write queue than the value set using WriteStream.setWriteQueueMaxSize

          Returns:
          true if write queue is full
